Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-05-29 18:55:31

@here I was talking to @David Larrea about CBA into modern O365 services (other than ActiveSync). Has anyone gone that route? As far as I can tell, O365 is going to consume the cert and allow/deny access based on the status of said cert. No IdP/IaM would be contacted, unless the CBA auth failed and a fall-back was in the policy. Does that sound accurate?

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-05-29 18:58:52

We're just implimenting cba into Outlook mobile.

We're going via ping as the identity broker to vet the cert then pass the auth off onto o365.

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-05-29 19:00:30

So, as with ActiveLogon in O365 if you specify a root CA to check for an identity certificate… can that be done for modern services as well? Or does it require a 3rd Party (such as Ping) to consume and provide assertion for access?

David Larrea (david@larreaonline.com)
2018-05-29 19:00:44

Hey everyone! So my understanding is that O365 will reach the IdP when using CBA in a Modern Auth scenario but not with ActiveSync i.e iOS 11 native mail client. In that scenario device will present cert to O365 which will check against CRL and will consume it without reaching IdP.

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-05-29 19:00:50

We'll be doing the same for teams and Yammer.

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-05-29 19:01:12

What I said mirrors what @David Larrea said, LoL

David Larrea (david@larreaonline.com)
2018-05-29 19:01:28

Haha

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-05-29 19:01:35

So O365 can’t/won’t handle a cert being directly presented to it for modern services

David Larrea (david@larreaonline.com)
2018-05-29 19:01:47

@Woody saw your post after I sent mine lol

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-05-29 19:02:12

*Thread Reply:* LoL - Great minds think alike!

David Larrea (david@larreaonline.com)
2018-05-29 19:02:19

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)

I’m curious why it was implemented that way. Perhaps there’s no way for a SP to consume a cert and provide assertion (because that’s the job of the IdP/IaM)

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-05-29 19:09:01

So, to summarize: For streamlined mobile access to O365, an IdP/IaM is going to need to natively consume the provided identity cert. Otherwise, they would need to perform some sort of IdP Discovery and hand-off to another IdP that can take care of it. Yes?

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-05-29 19:11:20

@Simon Hardy-Bistagne How does the config look to engage CBA into Outlook Mobile?

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-05-29 19:13:12

Auth redirect to ping Cert presented to ping Ping verifies the cert and the app header against the rules set (eg, outlook mobile can be granted access if cert presented, outlook desktop basic auth ok etc) Ping hands the authentication off

David Larrea (david@larreaonline.com)
2018-05-29 19:15:58

When using an MDM, the MS Authenticator app also has to be installed on the device so that the O365 app can access the Cert in the system’s Keychain.

👍 Woody, Alex Chappuis
Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-05-29 19:20:53

Nice tidbit of into there @David Larrea 👍

@here Is it possible to restrict access to O365 Modern Services to be accessed only from the likes of say the VMWare Boxer client?

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-09-18 22:03:57

Not without a 3rd party idp. Native conditional access will only allow you to restrict to either modern auth clients (in general) or the ms clients.

You’d need something like workspace one to lock the access down to only those apps.

👍 Woody
Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-09-18 22:08:41

Pretty sure the latest airwatch/workspace one uem platform allows you to deploy a modern auth profile over ActiveSync, not sure if that can be applied to boxer though... I hate the way boxer gets configured in airwatch.

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2018-09-19 03:30:32

@Simon Hardy-Bistagne That was my thought as well. I know there are some lightweight controls on the MSFT end, but you’re better using Workspace ONE to identify the app, device management state, etc and making the call

Roman Kleyn (kleyn.roman@web.de)
2018-09-24 20:15:12

We‘re in a Integration project for MSFT Teams. Just wondering if anyone can give me a advise. We use MI Core and have a iOS only device landscape. We use conditional access (on Azure) to secure access from managed locations only. We‘ve been successful with other apps like SharePoint by using AppTunnel. Since Tunnel doesn’t support UDP Split and UDP Tunneling over AnyConnect is not the best option for a global deployment, I was wondering if someone can share a strategy how to secure Teams, so it can be accessed from managed devices and from the managed app only.

We‘ve been trying to do it by tunneling MS Authenticator. However this is annoying for users, as Teams flips to Authenticator several times per day once the authentication token become not valid. Also this doesn’t make sure Teams is managed, so users can download from Public AppStore and DLP isn‘t ensured.

Thanks, Roman

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2018-09-24 20:18:18

Do you have an authentication provider for fedoration at all?

Microsoft have purposefully made it as hard as possible to use other emm platforms as a compliance flag.

🤯 Woody
Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2018-09-24 20:41:53

This is actually best solved with MobileIron Access. You would need a federation service, like ADFS though. With Access as a sort of federated IdP, being capable of determining the device and app posture by using the Core and support for split-tunneling (only authentication data for example), it seems to fulfill your needs. Implementing it does require some homework, as your Sentry(‘s) will become first in line for authentication communication for all Office365 apps. Be careful and map out of all the services, conditional rules, etc. before implementing it.

✅ Woody
Roman Kleyn (kleyn.roman@web.de)
2018-09-25 05:50:29

@Mark Vonk The problem here is that split tunneling on Access side is working for TCP traffic only. It doesn’t work for UDP based apps like S4B and Teams. This has been confirmed by MI as not supported

Roman Kleyn (kleyn.roman@web.de)
2018-09-25 05:51:19

MI currently doesn’t support split UDP on Tunnel for iOS

Wolfgang Bauer (wolfgang.bauer@lineas.de)
2018-09-25 07:13:54

Missed that UDP was used, that's probably the chat/video stuff from Skype4B that is being build into teams.. Indeed, in that case, currently, Access is not the solution. Access as a Service neither, it will have the same issue with UDP.

Here's information regarding the attribute msExchRemoteRecipientType that you can use in MI to build lables for automated migration (removing profile/app and installing new profile/app). Remember to set your LDAP sync time to a lower value then before, MI needs to know the LDAP changes for this to work. Using numers "4" and "20" as the desired values for migration has worked for me. Maybe I've used "6" as well. http://memphistech.net/exchange-recipient-types-and-office-365-setting-active-directory-attribute-values/

Kiran Patel (kiran@kiranpatel.net)

Kiran Patel (kiran@kiranpatel.net)
2019-02-25 17:54:03

*Thread Reply:* What are the pros/cons?

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-02-25 17:57:31

*Thread Reply:* CBA for Exchange works fine and is very seamless. Obviously most other services do not support CBA, especially cloud based. Also with Modern auth you can do more conditional based access on the fly. With CBA not possible except for revoking or removing the client cert. For example with modern auth, you can enforce MFA based on the location of a device and app login. With CBA the user is logged in with the cert regardless of the location.

👍 NicolasR, MichaelM21
Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-02-25 18:00:22

*Thread Reply:* IMO btw. Not my field of expertise. Some others might have more insights. Like @Woody and @Simon Hardy-Bistagne

Simon Hardy-Bistagne (simon@smnhdy.com)
2019-02-25 18:13:29

*Thread Reply:* So, they’re both different parts of the same puzzle. CBA is about the authentication, and Oauth is about the persistance of that session. You can have both together with the certificate carrying out the initial authentication, and Oauth keeping the session alive. CBA just replaces the need for a password upfront.

CBA in it’s own right though is a mixed bag.

“If” you can force the app to automatically select the certificate from the key store, then great. The UX is true SSO, and if you tie it to an IDP which can do some kind of tiered access (ala conditional access) you can tie all other kinds of rules around it.

The problems comes when you try to use certificates for websites, or for apps which you’re not able to have deep control over to select the certificate for the user. You then get this horrid UX where the user is asked to choose a cert from the key store, and then you get all kinds of problems.

Modern auth though is not just about the authentication mechanism, its also about the session length. Oauth in it’s default model means your session token lasts (i think) 90 days. With a cert, you’re authenticating every time. You can measure the pros and cons of that yourself.

One thing also to think about is that if you still use activesync, and you have a relatively large user base, you should be thinking about moving to modern auth. I would suggest reaching out to your IDP/IAM teams and seeing just how much of their overall authentication requests are carried out by activesync. For us, i know that up to half of all authentication requests globally are taken up just by activesync, and the move to modern auth releases so Mitch pressure on the IDP systems it’s unreal.

👍 Mark Vonk, MichaelM21, NicolasR, Woody

If the UPN doesn’t equal the email address within the AD, how should the SSO be done within the MobileIron Access Admin Portal? SSO for O365 works for users where the UPN matches the email address, but for users without that match it doesn’t work.

SCEP on Core: Subject = $UserUPN$ SANs: DN / $UserDN$ RFC 822 Name / $USERID$

SAML Attributes we use: Subject (Persistent / rfc822Name Instance 1) UserID (from rfc822Name: Instance 1) UserDomain ( from DirectoryName Instance 1)

So I think we should use the email address for SSO, not the UserID.

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-07-28 19:03:14

ImmutableID can be changed: not the value (obviously) but which user attribute is set to be the immutable. So you need to figure that out first. And work your way back to something that works. You can find the immutable by running a powershell command to Azure AD: https://www.google.nl/amp/s/debay.blog/2019/02/21/how-to-check-the-immutable-id-source-anchor/amp/ Nevertheless I would suggest first to make the UPN the same as the primary email address. If, in one environment, for some users the upn is different that for others, I would not even try to implement such a thing as Access before they sort out that mess....

My blog
} Camille Debay (https://debay.blog/author/camilledebay/)
How to check the Immutable ID/Source Anchor
This article expains how to check which attribute is used as the source anchor for the synchronization between Active Directory and Azure Active Directory. PowerShell 0 &ndash; Install necessary PowerShell Modules, if needed. Install-Module MSOnline Import-Module MSOnline 1 &ndash; Get User Immutable ID from Azure. Connect-MSOLService Get-MsolUser -UserPrincipalName user@domain.tld | select ImmutableID 2 &ndash; Convert to GUID Format [GUID][system.convert]::FromBase64String("User ImmutableID") 3 &ndash; Check against AD and check which one is corresponding $User = Get-ADUser -Identity username -Properties mS-DS-ConsistencyGUID [GUID]$User.'mS-DS-ConsistencyGUID' $User.ObjectGUID Azure AD Connect 1 &ndash; Go to Azure AD connect server and open Azure AD Connect 2 &ndash; Click on&nbsp;Configure 3 &ndash; Click on&nbsp;View current configuration then&nbsp;Next 4 &ndash; In the&nbsp;Synchronization Settings, look for&nbsp;Source Anchor
Original URL: https://www.google.nl/amp/s/debay.blog/2019/02/21/how-to-check-the-immutable-id-source-anchor/amp/

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-07-28 22:14:05

The ObjectGUID needs to be in the certificate. So on Core in the ldap config, custom1 needs to be assigned to the ObjectGUID attribute. This custom1 is then added to the SAN of the client cert as seen in your SCEP.

If I have a 90 day lifetime of my AAD refresh token, and use iOS Native mail, with Oauth2, what will happen after 90 days? And what will happen if a user change their password?

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-10-07 15:37:04

*Thread Reply:* User will need to login again after 90 days. If they change the password the user will need to enter the new password when the access token expires, by default one hour. See: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/active-directory-configurable-token-lifetimes

docs.microsoft.com
Configurable token lifetimes in Azure Active Directory
Learn how to set lifetimes for tokens issued by Azure AD.
Original URL: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/active-directory-configurable-token-lifetimes
Anton I (antonn94@gmail.com)
2019-10-09 08:34:26

*Thread Reply:* Thanks! Have you tested this yourself? Everyone seems to say that the refresh token is being refreshed automatically as well...very confusing as I get different answers from everyone.

Anton I (antonn94@gmail.com)
2019-10-09 08:36:08

*Thread Reply:* I think this is confirmed by this statement:

Refresh Token Max Inactive Time String: MaxInactiveTime

Affects: Refresh tokens

Summary: This policy controls how old a refresh token can be before a client can no longer use it to retrieve a new access/refresh token pair when attempting to access this resource. Because a new refresh token usually is returned when a refresh token is used, this policy prevents access if the client tries to access any resource by using the current refresh token during the specified period of time.

This policy forces users who have not been active on their client to reauthenticate to retrieve a new refresh token.

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-11-26 14:46:18

Is anyone using ADFS Cert Based Auth for Mobile Devices? We are looking for a way to implement SSO with the native mail client on iOS for our Exchange Online users! Is that possible with ADFS CBA?

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-11-26 15:14:17

*Thread Reply:* What you can do, is use Kerberos with iOS SSO and use the Kerberos ticket to have the device request a SAML token. That works for the native client pre iOS 13 SSO extension.

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-11-26 15:41:18

*Thread Reply:* This sounds interesting.. by any chance you have details on that?

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-11-26 15:44:14

*Thread Reply:* What MDM?

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-11-26 16:16:01

*Thread Reply:* MI Core or Intune

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-11-26 17:11:47

*Thread Reply:* Native iOS SSO uses Kerberos, you can push a iOS SSO config and include a client cert that allows for silent Kerberos ticket retrieval. Push that to the iOS devices. With MI you can use Tunnel to get access to the AD domain controller. The cert must be trusted by the ADDC so use a MS SCEP config for the client certs. On your internal (Tunnel) or external ADFS allow user authentication with Kerberos. Now, when a client is send to ADFS for modern Auth, the Kerberos ticket is used to authenticate and the experience is kind of seamless.

MichaelM21 (mike.miller815@yahoo.com)
2019-11-26 17:33:37

*Thread Reply:* Very cool, thanks Mark! Since Tunnel is needed, I guess Platinum licenses are needed. But good solution overall!

Bram Dc (bram.de.corte@xylos.com)
2019-11-26 22:51:19

*Thread Reply:* Since its Exchange online. Cant u use the federated managed appleids ?

Kiran Patel (kiran@kiranpatel.net)
2019-11-27 19:21:57

*Thread Reply:* if you have ADFS proxies available external Tunnel isn't needed I believe

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2019-11-27 19:23:32

*Thread Reply:* True for ADFS, but your device still needs to request and renew Kerberos tickets, most often from a Domain Controller... Tunnel is just a per app vpn, so most VPNs can do the same.

🙏 MichaelM21, Kiran Patel

Anton I (antonn94@gmail.com)
2020-03-31 14:20:39

*Thread Reply:* As far as I see it, just changing you refresh token wont do the trick. You'll need to change the Access token validity time to like 10 hours, then change the refresh token validity time to, lets say 9 hours. Then, when the access token is to be renewed, the refresh token is expired and the AuthN process is kicking in again with your third party IDP.

👍 Damian
Damian (support@expertmobilite.com)
2020-03-31 14:31:56

*Thread Reply:* We use the offline grace period in Intune MAM to control this, if no connection after 48h block the access and request a new authentication.

Ray Domingue (raydomingue@gmail.com)
2020-04-24 15:35:13

For what it's worth ... in our O365 environment in order to access Outlook/SharePoint/Teams on a mobile device all that was required was to have the Company Portal app installed alongside. (This is for Android only devices). The user didn't have to authenticate into it, they just had to have the app installed alongside it. Earlier this month Microsoft made a change were it now requires a Work Account to be added to the device.

For BYOD users on a MAM/BYOD policy this really isn't a concern as an account is added under Settings > Accounts their personal devices.

For a managed Android Enterprise Device Owner mode, we were blocking users from adding in accounts on their devices. With this change our users started getting access denied when trying to log into Teams/SharePoint. We had to allow the modification of accounts on devices. This also opens up users to add in their personal Gmail/Samsung/Yahoo, etc. accounts potentially. It's a risk our company doesn't really like with users that can potentially email/save company data outside of our environment. Our MDM doesn't support a granular control of which accounts can be added and which ones can be blocked.

Just wanted to throw this out there ...

👍 NicolasR, Sebastian

Peter Mohr (pm@conscia.com)
2020-06-06 12:50:49

*Thread Reply:* https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/identity/ad-fs/operations/configure-user-certificate-authentication

NicolasR (raison_nicolas@me.com)
2020-06-06 13:24:38

*Thread Reply:* As far I remember certificate can’t live with some of the auth methods on the same port. Maybe I’m mistaken, for me the form redirects to the cert based auth on a separate port (49443 by default so far I remember)

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2020-06-08 15:33:47

*Thread Reply:* So @Peter Mohr when you engage that in ADFS--is the user prompted to select a certificate or does it auto-match (like MI Apps@Work/etc) if it has a cert that identifies as being issued from a CA that ADFS trusts?

Peter Mohr (pm@conscia.com)
2020-06-08 15:56:27

*Thread Reply:* Yes. The ADFS will send a list of trusted CAs to the client. The client will filter certs to include only certs from that CA list. If there is just 1 (one) cert that we be auto selected. if more than 1 the user will be prompted.

❤️ Woody
Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2020-06-11 17:14:46

Peter Mohr (pm@conscia.com)
2020-06-11 20:07:30

*Thread Reply:* Well. I’m not 💯 but I sort of sure that your local certificate store (local machine account) has the ‘Enterprise Trusted Root’ store and that is used by ADFS.

Nick (nickdiaz@gmail.com)
2020-06-25 18:23:23

Is anyone using Samsung Mail to access Microsoft 365 using modern authentication? I'm told it's blocked by Microsoft, but don't have a source.

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2020-06-25 18:28:33

*Thread Reply:* Last time I checked Samsung mail with Office365, which was last week, it worked fine. There are some things though: the managed app configuration does not allow you to set the authentication method and expects username and password. Hence you are limited to basic auth and modern authentication does not work if you use the managed app configuration. This could limit your experience, for example if Conditional Access on Azure AD (legacy ActiveSync) or Exchange Online requires modern auth (and does not allow basic auth. Also, Azure AD conditional access might be set up to block any other client than Outlook. In other words, it does work, but your mileage may vary depending on the Azure AD and Exchange setup.

Nick (nickdiaz@gmail.com)
2020-06-25 18:32:46

*Thread Reply:* A managed app configuration is certainly the context. And with basic auth going away soon for M365, modern auth is the way forward. But my understanding is that Samsung Mail does support Modern Auth. Just trying to understand why Microsoft would block it.

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2020-06-25 19:42:02

*Thread Reply:* Samsung mail works with modern auth. Only not when using a managed appconfig. If I grab a Samsung and configure it myself for Office365, even with modern auth, it works fine.

Microsoft does not block Samsung mail. But maybe your specific setup does.

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2020-06-25 20:02:44

*Thread Reply:* Here is the config reference for Samsung Mail: https://docs.samsungknox.com/dev/samsung-email/index.htm

If you use this, Samsung mail will default to basic auth. If you block basic auth on either Azure AD conditional access or Exchange Online, Samsung Mail (as any other mail client that tries to use basic auth) will fail. If you use MFA for user auth, Samsung mail will fail too, as MFA requires modern auth. In that case you could use an Azure AD app password: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/user-help/multi-factor-authentication-end-user-app-passwords

docs.microsoft.com
How to manage app passwords - Azure Active Directory
Learn about app passwords and what they are used for with regard to two-step verification.
Original URL: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/user-help/multi-factor-authentication-end-user-app-passwords
Nick (nickdiaz@gmail.com)
2020-06-25 20:07:04

*Thread Reply:* Acknowledged that managed config can't do modern auth. Trying to understand the implications if using cert based auth to an IdP like ADFS gets around that.

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)
2020-06-25 20:12:00

*Thread Reply:* Yes it should. If ADFS is configured to consume client certs, that would work. Samsung Email supports CBA too.

Mark Vonk (mark.vonk@dahvo.com)

Is it possible to disable personal accounts for OneDrive app on iOS? Anyone have the app config keys for OneDrive?

Nico Hermeling (nico.hermeling@outlook.com)
2022-03-03 11:20:38

*Thread Reply:* Use IntuneMAMAllowedAccountsOnly and IntuneMAMUPN to block personal accounts.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-configuration-policies-use-ios#allow-only-configured-organization-accounts-in-apps

docs.microsoft.com
Add app configuration policies for managed iOS/iPadOS devices - Microsoft Intune
Learn how to use app configuration policies to provide configuration data to an iOS/iPadOS app when it is run.
Original URL: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-configuration-policies-use-ios#allow-only-configured-organization-accounts-in-apps

TGR (tgr@twise.dk)
2022-08-26 09:00:14

*Thread Reply:* I agree - no solution is perfect here as you would either allow exchange data to flow to any app (with modern auth) as long as the device is managed or you would allow for people’s name and phone number (not from GAL) to be stored in personal unmanaged storage. I’m not wise enough to know if this conflicts with GDPR, but that should definitely be investigated. And I agree that it’s not a very pretty solution, but from a zero trust perspective I don’t think allowing other (non app protected) apps access to exchange data is either.

Woody (eric.woodland@trust.tc)
2022-08-29 20:20:50

*Thread Reply:* @Peter Mohr Got it installed for my device. Appears to sync contacts for my mailbox. Could/Would it pull in the entire company directory? Or does it do that by default? Could/Would it also display Contacts in the O365 GAL that are external contacts?

Peter Mohr (pm@conscia.com)
2022-08-29 20:44:25

*Thread Reply:* It grabs the GAL (actually the user directory from Azure) and stores locally in a database. can be used as a phonebook just like that. If you want incoming calls to show the names allow the CallerID setting and the app will sync the contacts list into the native iOS callerID list (hidden from users). When an incoming call arrives at your phone and the caller is NOT in your local / personal store, the CallerID list is queried and the result from Phonebook app is show. Almost everything is configurable from MDM. But user must initiate the CallerID sync (once).

Damian (damian_mcmahon@icloud.com)
2024-04-09 10:53:01

Hey folks, does anyone have a link to documentation regarding which mobile apps share the AAD refresh token? We’ve been managing the auth for apps for many yrs now and it seems that certain apps are « token aware » such as Outlook & Teams whilst others such as Yammer are not and thus the user goes through another authentication workflow (we’re using mobileSSO by VMware which is transparent but not on the IDP level so it impacts the user experience.

Ryan Grimm (rgrimm@weismarkets.com)
2024-04-09 13:53:28

*Thread Reply:* @Damian All of Microsoft's SDM enlightened apps should be able to re-use the same tokens provided they're using MSAL for authentication.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity-platform/msal-android-shared-devices#microsoft-applications-that-support-shared-device-mode

👍 Damian
Damian (damian_mcmahon@icloud.com)
2024-04-10 07:51:40

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for this but we don’t use shared devices. I’m talking about a single user on their device not having to sign in multiple times to apps from the same company, in this case Microsoft. I am guessing that every Microsoft app is using MSAL.

Sascha Warno (sascha.warno@outlook.com)
2024-05-10 08:52:52

*Thread Reply:* Late to the game, you can use Authenticator(iOS) or Company Portal(Android) as authentication broker app and centralize authentication for all MSAL apps. Only time you should see reauth then is when an app has a different conditional access policy requiring higher assurance like MFA compared to the existing token.
